forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — the debt remains below $37T by June 27 on its recent trajectory.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Total Public Debt Outstanding sits in the mid–$36T range in early June and rises at a typical pace (~$100–200B/month after April’s tax inflows), keeping it below $37T by June 27; any ongoing debt ceiling constraints/extraordinary measures also cap headline growth.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Debt is already near ~$36.85–$36.95T and ordinary issuance pushes it over $37T by June 27; or Congress resolves the debt limit in June and Treasury’s restoration of extraordinary measures plus catch-up issuance produces a one-off jump of several hundred billion that clears $37T before/around June 27.
forecast.rationale:
- Evidence and base rates: Over the past couple of years, total debt has risen roughly $1.5–$2.5T per year (about $125–$200B per month), with a typical April dip/flattening from tax receipts and renewed increases in May–June. Given that cadence and only ~3 weeks left, a move of ~$300–$500B would be needed if the starting point is around the mid–$36T’s, which is unlikely without a one-off jump.
- Status quo weighting: In most years, daily debt changes are incremental. Absent a discrete policy/action shock, the most probable outcome is that June 27 prints below $37T.
- Upside pathways: A late-June debt-limit deal could trigger immediate restoration of suspended investments (extraordinary measures) and catch-up issuance—historically this can add hundreds of billions to reported totals quickly. If current levels are already very close to $37T, ordinary issuance alone could tip it over.
- Downside/No pathways: If the debt limit remains binding (with extraordinary measures in use), the headline total may be held near the ceiling, and normal seasonal patterns won’t deliver a >$300B jump in three weeks.
- Why not higher: Crossing $37T from a mid–$36T starting point requires an unusually large, rapid increase that typically only follows a debt-limit resolution with restorations; timing and magnitude are uncertain.
- Why not lower: There is real tail risk from a potential June debt-limit resolution causing a large, immediate step-up, and it’s possible the current level is already close enough that normal issuance suffices.
- What would change my view: Daily Debt to the Penny prints showing the level by mid-June; any confirmed news on a debt-limit agreement and timing of restoring extraordinary measures; unexpectedly large net borrowing plans or supplemental outlays; a confirmed current level at or above ~$36.9T would push my probability up; confirmation that the debt limit remains binding through late June would push it down.
